description.plain:
Christopher Charles Lloyd, also known by his stage name, Lloyd Banks or the Punch Line King (P.L.K), is a rapper from New York City, Queens. Banks' rap career was established in the early ‘90s with the formation of G-UNIT: a rap group led by 50 Cent that took the industry by storm around 2003-08.

Banks has collaborated with the very best in the industry such as Eminem, 50 Cent, Rakim, Raekwon, Jadakiss, Fabolous, and many more. Kanye West ranks Banks in his top 5 list.
As a solo artist, Banks has four studio albums and sixteen mixtapes under his belt, achieving platinum certifications by the RIAA. His most well-received recent projects are from his All or Nothing mixtape series: Failure’s No Option (2013) and Live It Up (2016). His dedication to mixtapes earned him the title, The Mixtape Champion.

Banks' early 2000’s musical style exhibited braggadocios elements and revolved around ghetto struggle/gang themes; expressed with a heavy-hitting punchline delivery. As Banks matured as an artist, his recent projects also matured, both in content and structural complexity.

The Queens rapper often takes long hiatuses between projects as he is known to prioritize quality over quantity; an outlook which is illustrated in his music through his authenticity and respect for rap as an art form.

songs.title: Start It Up
songs.title_with_featured: Start It Up (Ft. Fabolous, Kanye West, Ryan Leslie & Swizz Beatz)

description.plain:
“That was one of the last joints I recorded for my album,” Banks explained to MTV News. “Originally it was me and Fab, then I got Kanye, then Swizz was in the city and so was Ryan."

The G-Unit artist connected with Kanye West after the latter took to Twitter to declare Banks as one of the top five MCs in the industry.

Banks repaid the favor by featuring on one of Kanye’s tracks in return –  “Christian Dior Denim Flow”.

Negotiations occurred during the aftermath of this track for Banks to sign to G.O.O.D Music (West’s label), that were being handled by Chris Lighty (50 Cent’s manager). However after Lighty’s death, a deal never came to fruition.

description.plain: The third single from Lloyd Banks’s debut album, The Hunger for More, shows the calmer and more romantic side of Banks, which we don’t often get to see. It’s probably the closest-to-perfect description of the girl of his dreams, while singer Avant tells us, in opposition however, that he could never imagine a solid relationship with any type of female – especially this one.

songs.full_title: Beamer, Benz, or Bentley by Lloyd Banks (Ft. Juelz Santana)
songs.title: Beamer, Benz, or Bentley
songs.title_with_featured: Beamer, Benz, or Bentley (Ft. Juelz Santana)

description.plain:
“Beamer, Benz, or Bentley” is the first single from Lloyd Banks' 3rd album H.F.M.2 (The Hunger For More 2).

It was released as a digital download on February 9, 2010 and certified Gold by the US RIAA, moving more than 500,000 units. It was released with no major label promotion and reached #49 on the Billboard Hot 100. It features Juelz Santana on the second verse, chorus and is produced by Prime. Banks describes the song as a “club record with a lot of energy”.

Beamer, Benz or Bentley was featured on the official sound track of the 2012 comedy flick, Project X.

description.plain:
“i’m So Fly” was the second single replaced by G-Unit rapper Lloyd Banks, it went on to reach #2 on the hot 100 chart and was used as track #6 on his debut album, The Hunger For More.

The song features Banks showing off his star lifestyle and personality over a classic Timbaland beat.

songs.full_title: Warrior, Pt. 2 by Lloyd Banks (Ft. 50 Cent, Eminem & Nate Dogg)
songs.title: Warrior, Pt. 2
songs.title_with_featured: Warrior, Pt. 2 (Ft. 50 Cent, Eminem & Nate Dogg)

description.plain:
“Warrior Part 2” is track 9 of Lloyd Banks debut album, “The Hunger for More” (released June 29, 2004). The track is produced by Eminem, who’s also featured in the song with 50 Cent and Nate Dogg.

In this song we get to hear the story of four warriors who’s letting us know they’re the best in the game, and that other rappers can’t touch them. They’re warning haters not to start trouble, or they’ll be wrecked both lyrically and physically.

Even though Eminem yells “remix” in the intro, the song hasn’t sampled anything from another song. There’s another song from H.F.M. named “Warrior”, but the only similarities between the songs are the name. Maybe Eminem just wanted to make an continuation in his own style?

songs.title: On Fire

description.plain:
“On Fire” was the first single released by Lloyd Banks. Coming off his debut album The Hunger for More and reaching #8 on Billboard 100, the track ended up being his highest charting track.



The song samples The Mohawks' 1968 track, “The Champ”:

songs.full_title: Hands Up by Lloyd Banks (Ft. 50 Cent)
songs.title: Hands Up

description.plain:
“Hands Up” is the second single from Lloyd Banks' second studio album, Rotten Apple. The chorus is sung by fellow G-Unit member 50 Cent and the video features the former as well as another, G-Unit member Tony Yayo.

The song is produced by Eminem and was released as a digital download on July 25, 2006. “Hands Up” debuted at #84 on the Billboard Hot 100.

It is featured on the soundtrack of Saints Row 2, a video game released in 2008 which sold 3.5 million copies. Big rappers and big songs for big games.

songs.full_title: Officer Down by Lloyd Banks
songs.title: Officer Down

description.plain:
Banks' vicious diss aimed at fraud rapper Rick Ross in the wake of news breaking out that he’d been a correctional officer before pursuing hip-hop. 50 Cent, Lloyd Banks himself and G-Unit as a whole had a feud with fraud rapper rick ross for this very reason.

Banks is sick of fake, unauthentic and fraudulent rappers in the rap game and he’ll do his part in making it known to the world. Officer Down is an example of what Banks is capable of when pissed off.
